address.streetAddress: Toronto, ON 145 Queen St W Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts

description: Based in Toronto, the Canadian Opera Company (COC) is the largest producer of opera in Canada and one of the largest in North America. The company enjoys an international reputation for artistic excellence and creative innovation. The COC presents six fully-staged productions each season at the Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts.

reviews.title: The performances are well put together, but stage settings are mediocre... comfort and quiet are lacking.
text: The performances are very good, however It is extremely difficult to enjoy performances with the incessant audience noise! Also, seat comfort leaves much to be desired.

reviews.title: The COC really struggles with visual part of performances, and now - musics
text: The COC really struggles with the visual part of performances - many classic operas are staged with either industrial simple "grey-black & red spot" or pale brownish (also simplistic background). One might wonder if the decorators have only 2 options in mind. Occasionally for model operas, the director goes wild and over-decorates everything, so I wonder if there is hate to classics here. My favourite opera, Barber of Seville suffered there not only from the lack of practically any decor (COC put this Barocco-times opera into an empty grey space with just red grand-piano on the stage) but also from brutal handling of its beautiful music. Last Saturday they had an Italian female over-caffeinated conductor that seemed like worrying about attention to herself, considering over-gesturing than about the quality of music. She runs all music almost twice faster than it should be so poor professional (and usually great) orchestra barely had time to play complex passes. Singers had to mumble and not sing the music, as it was simply no time. The opening scene didn't come with much voicing as the singer was not up to the job, and the key Rosina's aria at the 2nd act. was rather mumbled as well. And this is what they do to the best opera ever... Very disappointing...

reviews.title: There probably a reason why they call themselves "Opera house" - shouldn't do ballet
text: Operas usually invite top singers, this is great but decor... are they that poor or color blind? But why 3 stars here is their ballet - ok, they try hard, I see how much they try but, Karen (director), please teach dancers to do tough ballet, including splits. The decor is also not there. The worth experience was, however when they have blue background and white-dressed dancers come, good music, group dancing, nice white-blue contrast but they are not synchronized, just about but not there. They can't even wave hands up and down in synchrony, forget jumping or lifting legs. It's painful to watch :(  The public, of course, like the dresses and applouses for anything. Today's orchestra at the 3rd performance was awful, I don't understand how it can be allowed, in 3 places - usually their orchestra is superb. This added to pain, and the tickets are not cheap - 250$. If they economize on decor and training, I wonder where do the money go to?

reviews.title: Free Concert Series - Amazing!
text: I love how the COC offers a Free Concert Series on certain Tuesdays-Wednesdays-Thursdays of the year. They have a wide range of talent and every time I attend, it’s so enjoyable! Most are held at 12 noon til 1 pm but on some Wednesdays there are 5 pm shows. Seating is limited but give it a try - it’s free!

reviews.title: Never disappoints
text: I have been attending COC productions since 1998 and I am never disappointed by their work, craft, and art.  Even when I do not enjoy the story line, I am always captivated by the sets.  I am in awe of the talent and artistry that is invested in every opera. It was a nearly full house on Saturday. Love seeing the arts being supported by folks!!

reviews.title: Great Opera
text: We attended Cosi Fan Tuttle at the Toronto Opera.  The production was excellent.  The building is beautiful and the acoustics seemed great.

reviews.title: Opt for Eugene Onegin
text: If you want a lavish production see the new Canadian opera " Hadrian".  World class singers but not world class music.   The first act was interesting colourful and more dynamic than the boring second act.   Leave at intermission.
On the other hand one can't argue with Tchaikovskys Opera "Eugene Onegin". Joyce El Khoury from Ottawa was excellent.  The male voices, so so.  Perhaps the orchestra was too loud for them at times.

The Canadian Opera Company is world class however   Any opera us worth a visit because the Four Seasons Centre is beautiful.   Bar prices are steep.  Stick to soft drinks and then listen to a wonderful company.

reviews.title: Nice, impressive
text: This is a nice, impressive building and in the same time impressive performances of some important opera of all times.

reviews.title: Stunning production
text: We just attended the opening of Anne Bolena with Sondra Ravanovsky.  We heard her perform this role at the Met 2 years ago. This production lacked none of the emotional impact. Voices, lighting, acting and attention to detail made this a stupendous success.

reviews.title: Fabulous
text: We experienced the COC on a Sunday afternoon. We sat in $150 orchestra seats. There were two 25 minute intermissions. The orchestra blasted out the beautiful voices of the talented singers. Most patrons dressed appropriately in sport coats, dress slacks, dressy tops or conservative dresses. However, the ushers should be empowered to ask patrons to cover up skimpy and see through clothing which are better for a nightclub than a Sunday afternoon at the opera. A female patron wore a pink slip dress with no underwear. She should have been asked to cover up.

reviews.title: Wonderful experiences
text: I started going to the COC as a high school student when they moved to the brand-new (and absolutely gorgeous) Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts.

I've gone to an average of 2-3 performances a season since 2007, each under the Opera for a New Age program. I highly recommend it for those under the cutoff age (35 I think). Currently, you can bring a guest of any age. For about $25 or $30, you can buy a ticket in one of a set of seating areas.
The acoustics are very clear from wherever you sit, though the side seating (on rings 3, 4, 5) tend to have slightly awkward viewing angles.

The orchestra is consistently excellent. I've seen productions of varying interest, though it's always a memorable and exciting experience. Nice little gift shop as well if you want to pick up a souvenir or two.

reviews.title: Not a single mirror within the wardrobe area…
text: You have to pay extra for a wardrobe. While this is common in north america, I still consider it very unappropriate for opera-house.
Also, guess what? There are no mirrors(!) in the wardrobe downstairs.
As for opera performance – I’m not an expert, hence no comment.

reviews.title: Wonderful productions
text: Came to see Benjamin Britten's  Peter Grimes sung by Ben Heppner.  It was fantastic.  I don't think I need to say any more.  Oh yes, the Four Seasons Centre is such a beautiful building and the acoustics are exceptional.

reviews.title: Always an expectional evening!
text: The Canadian Opera Company and Ballet at the Four Seasons Centre for the Performing Arts are jewels on the Canadian arts scene.
Their new venue is nothing short of spectacular! I have sat in many different places for opera, ballets and musicals and have never been disappointed with the accoustics, singing or music.
Wonderful modern architecture complements the area. Located right above a subway stop, you would never know it.
Go! You won't be disappointed!

reviews.title: Leading North American Opera
text: Rape.  Murder.  Betrayal.  Slavery.  Abuse of power.  All set to such riveting music that you can enjoy it without having any clue what's going on in the story.  This is opera.

So there's a European way of presenting it, and a North American way.  The COC is among the best at the North American way.  The North American way assumes that one is building an audience, that many people have seen very few operas, and that one must not stray far from the composer's original concept or the audience will get lost; yet that there's also a part of the audience that is hungry for an up-to-date, thoughtful interpretation of the story.  Operas written before Freud about topics such as incest can never be presented again the way they were before Freud.  Slavery was understood differently in the 1860s (e.g. during the American civil war) than in the 2010s.  So how to engage the experienced audience without losing the audience that's dipping their toes in the operatic water?  The COC walks this fine line better than anyone.
Every season, there are three groups of opera, two pairs and a triple.  The groups are chosen by theme.

The most recent three performances--Carmelites, Salome, and Lucia, have "losing your head" as the theme.  The nuns of the Order of Carmelites, in the French Revolution, continue to dialogue about the truth they believe and lose their heads by being guillotined.  In Salome, John the Baptist also continues to speak what he believes is the truth and gets his head chopped off at Salome's request by Herod's guards.  The head is placed, still dripping blood, in an acryllic salad bowl and given to Salome, who does a French kiss on its mouth, something that John the Baptist was not allowing while the head was still attached to his body.  Lucia di Lammermoor speaks the truth about whom she loves, and loses her head in the ordinary meaning of the world--she goes mad from stress--and ultimately drowns in the garden fountain.

The previous pair of operas was the Clemency of Titus by Mozart, and Tristan and Isolde by Wagner.  The theme was betrayal.  Titus is a tremendously generous Emperor who would not believe anything but the best about anyone without firm evidence but is nevertheless betrayed by one he loves; King Marke in T&I is a tremendously generous King of Cornwall who gives everything he can to his protegee, Tristan, and is betrayed by him.  The emotions are gut-wrenching.  Should these operas be presented as if the only interpretation is that the action happened centuries ago?  Or can they be brought into our present to allow us to feel even more poignantly the sting of betrayal?  COC does really, really well with its interpretations.
COC uses its limited budget for the things that matter--great voices, an excellent orchestra, and an acceptable conceptualisation of each opera.

COC is not Stadtoper or Volksoper Wien or any of the three Berlin operas, but neither are its audiences, nor the governments that fund it.  Given the inputs, Canadians can be proud of how well their national opera company produces outputs!

If you're not a subscriber, and especially if you're a North American tourist, even from New York or Los Angeles, come see and be impressed!  If you're an European opera goer, you will be disappointed unless you change your expectations.  But as Dorothy famously said--you're not in Europe any more, Toto!

reviews.title: This is leading-edge opera!
text: Recently went to see SALOME and DIALOGUES OF THE CARMELITES at the Four Season's Centre. Both performances were just wonderful! Atom Egoyan made SALOME the best version I have ever seen. And...Isabel Bayrakdarian's performance was moving. I find it a difficult opera dramatically but love the music. This time I loved the whole thing. And CARMELITES was so beautifully performed that you had to cry.  Standing ovation!

reviews.title: Lucia di Lammermoor
text: American Anna Christy in the lead role was outstanding in the Donizetti opera.  Spectacular voices and a dark vision of madness.  Haunting, thrilling and highly entertaining.

reviews.title: Always a fabulous night at the Opera
text: Every time we are in Toronto we try to plan an evening out at the Opera. Beautiful piece of architecture, great performances, very good sound. Also a very good shop for Opera and Music lovers. A must go in Toronto.

reviews.title: Canadians should be proud!
text: We just spent several days in Toronto and had our first visit to the Four Seasons Performing Arts Centre and a performance by the Canadian Opera Company. It was a wonderful experience and we were thrilled by the quality of the venue and of the performance. The beautiful playing by the COC Orchestra was especially memorable. No need to go to Europe or New York - it is right here!

reviews.title: Hit a High Note
text: If you haven't been to an Opera, you definitely need to attend a Canadian Opera Company presentation.  It makes for a marvellous night out, before or after dinner.

reviews.title: Incredible!
text: We enjoyed the last showing of Madame Butterfly this past week and it was truly incredible.  I have seen the show before but felt the COC rendition was spectacular.  The musicians and performers were spot on. Butterfly and Pinkerton's voice was heart stopping.  The Four Seasons Center was a great venue felt classy but relaxed.  The Opera itself is a masterpiece, but the COC elevated the experience.  Bravo!

reviews.title: Falstaff is an oaf everyone will love!
text: Falstaff, the opera currently being performed at the COC's Four Seasons Centre is a gem.
I am not easily impressed but I must say that the acting, singing, facial expressions, staging, lighting, sets and of course the music and the orchestra were all PERFECT!

I wouldn't change a thing. For a change, the COC got it all right. It truly was amazing, even the performers motions, glances etc in time/synch with the music. 1960s sets including an amazingly bright and perfect kitchen was a very well received. Even a live horse munching away on some in one scene. I've seen a set applauded before. A very rare, immediate, and virtually unanimous standing ovation.
If you don't go and see this, you'll regret it.
Thank you COC!

reviews.title: Best Acoustic's of Any Opera House
text: Saw Madame Butterfly while in the city. The opera was very well done from the technical aspects to the quality voices of the performers.

reviews.title: Beautiful building, wonderful shows and venues
text: I haven't been for a while, but I have been coming here since it first opened, and many of the shows I've seen were wonderfully done, with beautiful costumes and imagery, and the talents are magnificent.

The bar area in between shows is lovely and the staff are all very warm and welcoming. The whole building is full of magnificent architecture, and the theatre is wonderfully designed, the sound carries so magnificently. I have only ever sat in the box seats so I cannot comment on how the downstairs of the theatre looks but I am sure it is as marvellous as the rest of the building.
The only issue was that, just before you enter the box, the wardrobe/coat hanging area was very dimly lit, so it was hard to see and find the hanger for my coat.

reviews.title: Bravo
text: There is better music,art, drama and dance in Canada than anyplace else. The Opera company is world class. The streets have lots of character and above all one of the safest places you will ever find.  The restaurants are eclectic and fit any pocket book.  Toronto embraces cultural diversity.  Make Toronto Island a must see, the skyline from the ferry is unsurpassed.

reviews.title: Stellar facility and hopefully a great performance to go with it
text: The Four Seasons Center is superb. Had seats on the upper balcony and still had great views and the sound is impeccable. Having been to the Met in NY and the Chandler Pavillion in L.A. I would say that the C.o.C. has the best performance venue. Have seen Peter Sellars' Tristan & Isolde and Atom Egoyan's Cosi Fan Tutte which were incredibly different and equally brilliant.

reviews.title: COC - spectacle, opera
text: Had seasons tickets to the Opera this year. Productions varied, but were challenging, moving and fun. Always exciting to go out and see live theatre with live music. All-round great experience, and a lovely venue.

reviews.title: Beautiful
text: Didn't care for the opera we saw but wanted to experience the facility - simply beautiful.  We got rush tickets and it was well worth it to spend a few hours sitting and taking it all in.  Recommend a visit.

reviews.title: Not First Rate
text: As an avid opera fan I do not go to the Canadian Opera Company.  The staging and costumes are always so dark and dingy. Their production do Aida was one of the worst seen in living memory. However good the singing is you might as well buy the CD  and not pay the steep prices. Use your money to see Live from the Met at $20:00 a seat

reviews.title: Lunch Concerts at Richard Bradshaw Amphitheatre
text: The amphitheatre is actually a gorgeous 2 story hall where concerts are given during lunch time. I went there last Tuesday with my 5 year old grandson to listen to music composed by John Adams for 2 pianos. The composer himself was there to give an introduction to his work and about the pianists. The acoustics are wonderful and the atmosphere very informal. This concert was part of six series: vocal, piano, jazz, dance, chamber and world music. Coming Thursday there will be opera.....and I hope to be there again. Just wonderful!

reviews.title: The Magic Flute
text: The venue in Toronto is exquisite. The story and the music were consistently very good. The performances were also very good.

reviews.title: Gotterdammerung Gotta Go (See it!)
text: Simply Amazing!  COC?  You nailed it.  Mrs & I saw the Ring Cycle in its entirety when Four Seasons Centre opened in Sept. 2006.  Richard Bradshaw was great, as was the entire Ring Cycle.  I wish CVOC would present the "cycle" again.  2017 version, first since that grand opening more than 10 years ago, was fantastic.  The orchestra outdid itself as did the cast.  It left me chocked up, as a good opera should - and only a great one can.  Greed, Power, Lust, Revenge; Wagner hit all the notes that are still relevant today.  So Poignant.  Well done COC.
If you like opera, even little, you need to go and see this epic tale.

reviews.title: GÖTTERDÄMMERUNG, damn good!
text: I just attended a working session for Wagner's last part of the Ring cycle. Full disclosure..I enjoy opera..only one of my friends that does. My first time at a working session. Great way to learn what's happening, what the Director, Conductor are trying to achieve, what the cast and orchestra have to work through.
Very cool to see the behind the scenes. The orchestra is PRO!!
The cast is outrageous, especially  Christine Goerke, she has a killer voice and was having a great time.
I have to get to the actual performance in February.

reviews.title: Nice visit to see Norma
text: We took my elderly Mom to see Norma as she is an opera buff and were not diappointed with the quality of the performance and the excellent acoustics. The building itself is very nice but not beautiful as some opera theatres built many years ago (ie Teatro Colon). It is very functional however we found there wasnt much leg room in the A rows in the 3rd ring. We were able to park underground and there was a elevator which was helpful for those with walking challenges

reviews.title: Norma
text: We've been COC subscribers for 20 years.  Norma was one of the best ever!  If you like opera, you need to see and hear this presentation!  All I can say about the lead performers and the orchestra is Bravo!

reviews.title: Amazing shows, beautiful building and lovely architecture!
text: A really nice place to visit for operas. The building architecture is beautiful, the staff is courteous and shows are amazing. All in all, Canadian Opera Company offers a really enjoyable experience.

reviews.title: Architectural interesting building.
text: Always provides an excellent selection of opera at a reasonable price. Visually pleasing architecture. Friendly staff.

reviews.title: For opera lovers , great place to visit.
text: The company presents amazing work. Opera singers with comparable quality of Europeans ones. The theatre has excellent acoustics .

reviews.title: Don Giovanni: musically exhilarating, dramatically much less so
text: My wife and I expected much from this, given the buzz that had surrounded Dmitri Tcherniakov's production. We were disappointed. The singing was great, with Russell Braun as the Don and Kyle Ketelsen as Leporello heading a very strong cast. The orchestra was also excellent. The production, however, was static, mystifying and boring. When a director explains his conception, you must hope that it becomes apparent on the stage. In this case it didn't, partly because the libretto contradicted the conception, and partly because the decision to stage everything in the Commendatore's library undermined the action. My wife left at the intermission; so did several other people in our area. I stayed because the music is gorgeous and the singers delightful, and because I wanted to see how the deception scene worked in Tcherniakov's version. It didn't, because Donna Elvira was clearly not deceived. This was only one of many mystifying touches in this production. Another: if Zerlina is Donna Anna's daughter, why is she referred to as "a peasant girl"? I could go on.

Having recently attended Robert Falls's superb production of Don Giovanni in Chicago and Joel Ivany's delightful adaptation of the opera in #Uncle John, Tcherniakov's production struck me as pretty thin beer. Obviously there were those who liked it (though I'm puzzled why), but when the director appeared for his bow I heard boos, unusual at the Four Seasons Centre.
Musically excellent, dramatically inadequate; call the combined result average.

reviews.title: Gone downhill
text: I used to frequent the COC when they first set up shop and while I don't want to discredit the performers whatsoever, I can't say the experience is that great anymore. The Four Seasons venue is great, very modern--definitely not your old school European opera house, which is good or bad, depending on who you ask.

The opera is hardly sacred around here anymore...the costumes often have a Rocky Horror-ness about it and I've noticed the past few times I've gone to see a performance, not only has wardrobe seemingly taken cutbacks, but so too have the sets! I don't understand how this is even possible as ticket prices aren't going down and patronage hasn't wained from what I can see (unless I'm just attending uber-popular shows), so I can't help but feel I'm being gouged. Thank goodness there's still the LED screen with lyrics as there'd be no other way of following the story!
